member.summary: Gets or sets the orientation of the Rating control. This determines the direction that icons are drawn next to each other.

member.name: F:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RatingOrientation.Horizontal
member.summary: Icons are layed out horizontally next to each other.

member.name: F:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RatingOrientation.Vertical
member.summary: Icons are layed out vertically on top of each other.

summary.para: Represents the types of precisions.

member.name: F:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RatingPrecision.Full
member.summary: When set to Full, icons are never partially filled. They can either be filled or not.

summary.para: When set to Half, the can be filled, half filled, or not filled at all, rounded up. For example, if ItemCount is 5, and the Value is 2.1, then the first two icons will be fully filled, and the third will be half filled.

member.name: F:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RatingPrecision.Exact
member.summary: When set to Exact, icons will be partially filled to try to exactly represent the Rating control's Value property.

member.name: T:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RatingValueType
member.summary: Value representing the type of value used for the Rating control.

member.name: F:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RatingValueType.Exact
member.summary: When set to Exact, the Rating’s Value will represent the exact icon value. For example, a value of 3 would mean that the first 3 icons are filled, no matter how many icons there are in total.

member.name: F:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RatingValueType.Percentage
member.summary: When set to Percentage, the Rating’s Value represents a percentage value (Min=0.0, Max = 1.0). For example, a value of 0.50 would mean that the first 50% is filled (if the Rating control has 5 stars, then the Value would represent the first 3.5 icons).

summary.para: Represents an editor that allows a user to pick a file from the disk.

Creates a shape for use by a gauge in the form of a pie slice, a full circle, or a circle with a flat base as shown. Does not include the tick marks, labels, markers or the pointer. The shape is determined by range, in degrees, of the StartAngle and EndAngle. If the range is 90 degrees or less, it will be a pie slice. A range of 360 degrees is a full circle. A range between 90 and 360 is a circle with a flat base.
Shown: Pie slice, circle with flat base.
Represents the data used by a portion of a Gauge. A portion is a part of the RadialGauge that can have custom color and margin.
Shown here is a RadialGauge with two portions.
Represents a Button that contains an icon and some data.
The Foreground, Background and BorderBrush can be easily modified with properties, while the Icon location is customizable.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.GaugePortion.PortionSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the percentage of the RadialGauge covered by the GaugePortion. For example, if the first GaugePortion's PortionSize is set to 30, it will cover (and let you customize the margin and color of) the first 30% of the gauge's displayed range of values. If a second GaugePortion is 70, the second portion will cover the 30% to 100% displayed range of values.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.MultiCalendar.ColumnCount
member.summary: Gets of sets the number of columns to use to display the calendars of the MultiCalendar control. The value is adjusted automatically when the property MonthCount changes. However, as soon as a custom value is assigned, this custom value will remain and no longer be adjusted automatically. If the combination of the properties ColumnCount and RowCount is not big enough for the property MonthCount, the MonthCount will be modified to fit based on the ColumnCount/RowCount provided.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.MultiCalendar.DisplayDateEnd
member.summary: Gets of sets the last day available in the MultiCalendar control. If the combination of the properties DisplayDateStart and DisplayDateEnd is not big enough for the property MonthCount, the MonthCount will be modified to fit based on the DisplayDateStart/DisplayDateEnd provided.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.MultiCalendar.DisplayDateStart
member.summary: Gets of sets the first day available in the MultiCalendar control. If the combination of the properties DisplayDateStart and DisplayDateEnd is not big enough for the property MonthCount, the MonthCount will be modified to fit based on the DisplayDateStart/DisplayDateEnd provided.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.MultiCalendar.FirstDisplayedDate
member.summary: Gets the first date that is currently displayed in the MultiCalendar control.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.MultiCalendar.HideInactiveDates
member.summary: Gets of sets if the inactive dates will be displayed at beginning and end of each calendar in the MultiCalendar control. Default is true.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.MultiCalendar.HighlightedDates
member.summary: Gets of sets the collection of dates that are marked as highlighted through all the calendars.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.MultiCalendar.MonthCount
member.summary: Gets of sets the number of calendars to display in the MultiCalendar control. Default is 2. If values are not provided for propreties ColumnCount and RowCount, they will be filled with values based on MonthCount. If values are provided for properties ColumnCount and RowCount, and the MonthCount doesn't fit in the ColumnCount/RowCount because too big, the MonthCount will be modified to fit based on the ColumnCount/RowCount provided.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.MultiCalendar.MonthlyBackgrounds

member.summary: Gets of sets the style to use for the button changing to previous month in the MultiCalendar control.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.MultiCalendar.RowCount
member.summary: Gets of sets the number of rows to use to display the calendars of the MultiCalendar control. The value is adjusted automatically when the property MonthCount changes. However, as soon as a custom value is assigned, this custom value will remain and no longer be adjusted automatically. If the combination of the properties ColumnCount and RowCount is not big enough for the property MonthCount, the MonthCount will be modified to fit based on the ColumnCount/RowCount provided.

member.name: M:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the RadialGauge class.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.ActualValue
member.summary: Gets the current Value of the RadialGauge regardless of whether the pointer is at rest or animating.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.BackgroundImage
member.summary: Gets or sets the image to display within the RadialGauge.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.BackgroundImageOffsetX
member.summary: Gets or sets the X offset of the BackgroundImage displayed in the RadialGauge.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.BackgroundImageOffsetY
member.summary: Gets or sets the Y offset of the BackgroundImage displayed in the RadialGauge.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.BGPortions
member.summary: Gets or sets the Collection of Background GaugePortions.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.BorderPortions
member.summary: Gets or sets the collection of Border portions of the RadialGauge.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.EndAngle
member.summary: Gets or sets the end angle of the RadialGauge, in degrees. Angle 0 is the top, 90 is the right, 180 is the bottom and 270 is the left.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.Fill
member.summary: Gets or sets the brush that is used to fill the RadialGauge's background.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.IsFullCircleBackground
member.summary: Gets or sets whether or not the RadialGauge will be represented as a full circle, even if the StartAngle and EndAngle do not give a 360 degree gauge.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.IsNumericIndicatorVisible
member.summary: Gets or sets if the NumericIndicator is displayed.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.IsPointerCapVisible
member.summary: Gets or sets if the pointer cap at the center of the gauge is displayed.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.IsPointerVisible
member.summary: Gets or sets if the gauge's pointer is displayed.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.IsTickLabelRotated
member.summary: Gets or sets if the label on the MajorTicks will be rotated to follow the tangent of its position along the circumference of the RadialGauge.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.IsTickLabelVisible
member.summary: Gets or sets if the label on the MajorTicks is displayed. The labels are the numbers of the scale shown on the RadialGauge.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.IsTickMarkVisible
member.summary: Gets or sets if the marks of the Ticks will be visible. A tick is composed of a mark and a label. The label is the numeric graduation value shown. The mark is the line on the scale of the RadialGauge.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.MajorTickCount
member.summary: Gets or sets the count of MajorTicks on the RadialGauge. MajorTicks are the main tick marks of the RadialGauge.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.MajorTickCustomLabels
member.summary: Gets or sets the major tick labels in the RadialGauge. For example, when you want to display 'North', 'South', 'East', 'West' instead of numeric values, you can fill this property with the string value "North,South,East,West". Starting from the first MajorTick, the MajorTick labels will be replaced with the comma-separated substrings.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.MajorTickLabelOffset
member.summary: Gets or sets the offset of the MajorTick labels from the center of the RadialGauge. A positive value will push the markers away from center while a negative value will pull them toward the center of the RadialGauge.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.MajorTickLabelTemplate
member.summary: Gets or sets the DataTemplate to be used for the MajorTick Labels.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.MajorTickMarkTemplate
member.summary: Gets or sets the DataTemplate to be used for the MajorTick marks. The new MajorTickMarkTemplate needs to be defined inside, at top-left, of a rectangle with (0,0) for top-left and (x,x) for bottom right.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.MarkerOffset
member.summary: Gets or sets the offset to use for Markers on the RadialGauge. A positive value will push the markers away from center while a negative value will pull them toward the center of the RadialGauge.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.Markers
member.summary: Gets or sets the collection of markers in the RadialGauge. Markers represent marks along the RadialGauge to identify important Values.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.MarkersTemplate
member.summary: Gets or sets the DataTemplate to be used for the Markers. The new MarkerDataTemplate needs to be defined inside, at top-left, of a rectangle with (0,0) for top-left and (x,x) for bottom right.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.Maximum
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum value of the scale of the RadialGauge.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.MiddleTickCount
member.summary: Gets or sets the count of MiddleTick divisions in the RadialGauge. MiddleTicks are divisions in between MajorTicks on the RadialGauge. A tick shape will be displayed between each division. To clarify, MiddleTicks counts the number of divisions created between MajorTicks, not the number of actual tick shapes displayed. To display 1 tick shape, set MiddleTickCount to 2. Setting MiddleTickCount to 1 will not display any tick shapes for the major ticks.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.MiddleTickMarkTemplate
member.summary: Gets or sets the DataTemplate to be used for the MiddleTick marks. The new MiddleTickMarkTemplate needs to be defined inside, at top-left, of a rectangle with (0,0) for top-left and (x,x) for bottom right.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.Minimum
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum value of the scale of the RadialGauge.

summary.para: Gets or sets the count of MinorTick divisions in the RadialGauge. MinorTicks are divisions in between MiddleTicks and MajorTicks on the RadialGauge. A tick shape will be displayed between each division. To clarify, MinorTicks counts the number of divisions created between MajorTicks and MiddleTicks, not the number of actual tick shapes displayed. To display 1 tick shape, set MinorTickCount to 2. Setting MinorTickCount to 1 will not display any tick shapes between the major ticks and middle ticks.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.MinorTickMarkTemplate
member.summary: Gets or sets the DataTemplate to be used for the MinorTick marks. The new MinorTickMarkTemplate needs to be defined inside, at top-left, of a rectangle with (0,0) for top-left and (x,x) for bottom right.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.NumericIndicatorOffsetX
member.summary: Gets or sets the X offset of the NumericIndicator. A positive value will move the NumericIndicator to the right while a negative value will move it to the left.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.NumericIndicatorOffsetY
member.summary: Gets or sets the Y offset of the NumericIndicator. A positive value will move the NumericIndicator down while a negative value will move it up.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.NumericIndicatorTemplate
member.summary: Gets or sets the DataTemplate to be used for the NumericIndicator.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.PointerCapStyle
member.summary: Gets or sets the Style to be used for the PointerCap.

summary.para: Gets or sets the offset from the center to display the Pointer from. A positive value will push the Pointer away from center while a negative value will pull it toward the center of the RadialGauge.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.PointerTemplate
member.summary: Gets or sets the DataTemplate to be used for the Pointer. The new PointerDataTemplate needs to be defined inside, at top-left, of a rectangle with (0,0) for top-left and (x,x) for bottom right. The Pointer should be pointing straight up.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.PointerTooltipTemplate
member.summary: Gets or sets the DataTemplate to be used for the tooltip of the Pointer.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.StartAngle
member.summary: Gets or sets the start angle of the RadialGauge, in degrees. Angle 0 is the top, 90 is the right, 180 is the bottom and 270 is the left.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.Stroke
member.summary: Gets or sets the brush to use for the stroke of the RadialGauge. The stroke is the border drawn around the gauge.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.StrokeThickness
member.summary: Gets or sets the Thickness of the stroke on the RadialGauge.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.SweepDirection
member.summary: Gets or sets the direction to draw the RadialGauge between StartAngle and EndAngle, either ClockWise or CounterClockWise.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.TickMarkOffset
member.summary: Gets or sets the offset to be used for the gauge's tick marks. A positive value will move the tick marks away from center while a negative value will move them toward the center of the radialGauge.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.Value
member.summary: Gets or sets the value of the RadialGauge. The Pointer will point to or animate towards this value.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.RadialGauge.ValueAnimation
member.summary: Gets or sets the animation that will be used for the pointer when the RadialGauge's Value property is modified. Animation types include None, Linear, BackEase, PowerEase, ElasticEase, and BounceEase.

member.summary: Gets or sets the step size (increase/decrease amount) used by the sliders. Used when the user clicks in the range areas (not the thumbs). Not used when interactively dragging the thumbs.

member.name: M:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Rating.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the Rating class.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Rating.ActiveBorderColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the Brush for the outer border (Stroke) of the icons that are in the active state.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Rating.ActiveFillColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the Brush to use to fill in the interior area of icons that are in the active state.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Rating.CustomPath
member.summary: Gets or sets the custom path for the icons to use.

summary.para: Gets or sets the direction of the fill used by the Rating control. This useful when Precision is set to Half or Exact. You can have the icons fill from left to right, top to bottom, and other directions. Please note, this is independent of the Orientation that determines the direction icons are drawn next to each other.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Rating.HoverBorderColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the Brush for the outer border of icons that are in the hover state.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Rating.HoverFillColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the Brush for the outer border of icons that are in the hover state.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Rating.IconHeight
member.summary: Gets or sets the height of the icons, in pixels.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Rating.IconPadding
member.summary: Gets or sets the padding between each icon.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Rating.IconStrokeThickness
member.summary: Gets or sets the icon border's Stroke thickness. The Stroke represents the outer border.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Rating.IconType
member.summary: Gets or sets the predefined or custom shape used to draw the icons.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Rating.InactiveBorderColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the Brush for the outer border of icons that are in the inactive state.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Rating.InactiveFillColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the Brush for the outer border of icons that are in the inactive state.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Rating.ItemCount
member.summary: Gets or sets the total number of icons.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Rating.LabelPosition
member.summary: Gets or sets the position of the labels with respect to the their associated icons. If set to Before, The label will appear above (Horizontal Orientation) or to the left (Vertical Orientation) of the icon. If set to After, the label will appear under (Horizontal Orientation) or to the right (Vertical Orientation) of the icon.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Rating.Orientation
member.summary: Gets or sets the orientation of the icons. This determines the direction that icons are drawn next to each other. Use FillDirection to determine afterwards if you want the icons to go from left to right, right to left, top to bottom, or bottom to top.

summary.para: Gets or sets a value representing the type of precision to use. When set to Full, icons are never partially filled. They can either be filled or not. When set to Exact, icons will be partially filled to try to exactly represent the Rating control's Value property.

When set to Half, the can be filled, half filled, or not filled at all, rounded up. For example, if ItemCount is 5, and the Value is 2.1, then the first two icons will be fully filled, and the third will be half filled.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Rating.ReadOnly
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the input control is read-only.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Rating.ShowLabels
member.summary: Gets or sets if the labels should be displayed.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Rating.ShowValueTooltip
member.summary: Gets or sets if the value tooltip should be displayed.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Rating.Value
member.summary: Gets or sets the current rating value.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Rating.ValueType
member.summary: Gets or sets the type of value used. When set to Exact, the Rating’s Value will represent the exact icon value. For example, a value of 3 would mean that the first 3 icons are filled, no matter how many icons there are in total. When set to Percentage, the Rating’s Value represents a percentage value (Min=0.0, Max = 1.0). For example, a value of 0.50 would mean that the first 50% is filled (if the Rating control has 5 stars, then the Value would represent the first 3.5 icons).

member.name: E:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.TokenizedTextBox.QueryItemFromText
member.summary: This event can be handled to extend the way a text input is converted to the corresponding item. Text input may be typed by the user or specified through the Text property. The query results have priority over the values underlined by the TokenDisplayMemberPath property.

member.name: E:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.TokenizedTextBox.QuerySuggestItemForText
member.summary: This event can be handled to extend the way a text input is considered to be a search match for an item. Search matches are displayed in the dropdown suggestion box. The query results have priority over the values underlined by the SearchMemberPaths property.

member.name: E:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.TokenizedTextBox.QueryTextFromItem
member.summary: This event can be handled to extend the way a token is converted to text for displaying, matching text, or for updating the Text property. The query result have priority over the values underlined by the TokenDisplayMemberPath property.

member.name: F:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Chart.AxisLabelLayout.ShowAll

member.name: F:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Chart.AxisLabelLayout.ShowToFit
member.summary: Every second, third, fourth label, etc., is hidden when there is not enough space to show the labels side-by-side.

member.summary: The range spans from the lowest value to the highest value of the data points.

summary.para: Xceed's WPF chart control is designed to display rich, flexible, configurable, extendable charts. The control is 100% lookless and is able to display multiple areas with multiple charts at the same time. It supports area, column (bar), line, and pie charts, and also provides the ability to create custom charts.

summary.para: This multi-value converter is used in the CollectionControl template to determine the list of possible new item types that will be shown in the combo box.

If the second value (i.e., CollectionControl.NewItemTypes) is not null, this list will be used. Otherwise, if the first value (i.e., CollectionControl.ItemsSourceType) is a IList<T> type, the new item type list will contain "T".

member.name: T:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Media.Animation.IterativeEquationConverter
member.summary: The converter used to convert IterativeEquation to a specific PennerEquation defined in the PennerEquations class based on a string. This comes in really handy when we are creating the "IterativeDoubleAnimation" in markup. All we need to do is set the "Equation" property on the IterativeDoubleAnimation to a string corresponding to a PennerEquation from the PennerEquations class.

member.summary: This is a type of IterativeEquation which animates double values.

member.summary: This class contains a rich set of pre-defined PennerEquations and their implementations. Any of the PennerEquations can be used as the equation for an IterativeEquation.

member.name: M:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Media.Animation.IterativeEquation`1.Evaluate(System.TimeSpan,`0,`0,System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: This method will invoke a delegate which in turn points to a method with the actual implementation of the equation.

member.name: M:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Media.Animation.PennerEquation.Evaluate(System.TimeSpan,System.Double,System.Double,System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: This method will invoke a delegate which in turn points to a method with the actual implementation of the equation. If we need to create a custom animation one of the methods that needs to be implemented/overrided is GetCurrentValueCore. When a PennerEquation is set as the "Equation" property of a custom animation like IterativeDoubleAnimation, this method is called from the GetCurrentValueCore method of the custom animation.
member.param: current time of the animation clock within its current iteration
begining value for the animation
ending value for the animation
The Duration property specifies the simple duration for a Timeline. The simple duration is the length of time that it takes to complete a single forward iteration of the time segment.

member.summary: Items are stretched in the direction perpendicular to the orientation of the timeline. If conflicts occur, the available space is divided between any conflicting items

member.summary: Items are hidden when a conflict occurs

member.summary: Elements are placed on top of one another

<b:Canvas LayoutAnimator="BackEaseIn" />

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Panels.AnimationPanel.DefaultAnimationRate
member.summary: Gets or sets the DefaultAnimationRate property. This dependency property indicates the duration or speed at which other animations will if they set their respective AnimationRate properties to AnimationRate.Default. This property can be used to set a single animation rate to be used for EnterAnimationRate, ExitAnimationRate, LayoutAnimationRate, SwitchAnimationRate, and TemplateAnimationRate.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Panels.AnimationPanel.DefaultAnimator
member.summary: Gets or sets the EnterAnimator property. This dependency property indicates which iterative layout animator will be used to animate children when they are first added to a panel. This provides for an "animate in" effect. If you'd like to use the same animator for several layouts within a SwitchPanel, you can set the EnterAnimator property directly on the owning SwitchPanel. Otherwise, setting this property on an animation panel will override the value of the owning SwitchPanel.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Panels.AnimationPanel.EnterAnimationRate
member.summary: Gets or sets the EnterAnimationRate property. This dependency property indicates the duration or speed at which "enter" animations occur within the panel. If null is specified and the panel belongs to the Layouts collection of a SwitchPanel, then the EnterAnimationRate property of the SwitchPanel will be used. If null is specified and the panel is being used standalone, then a default speed of 1 will be used. To prevent animations within the panel, you can explicitly set the speed property to 0 or simply set the IsAnimated property to false.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Panels.AnimationPanel.EnterAnimator
member.summary: Gets or sets the EnterAnimator property. This dependency property indicates which iterative layout animator will be used to animate children when they are first added to a panel. This provides for an "animate in" effect. If you'd like to use the same animator for several layouts within a SwitchPanel, you can set the EnterAnimator property directly on the owning SwitchPanel. Otherwise, setting this property on an animation panel will override the value of the owning SwitchPanel.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Panels.AnimationPanel.ExitAnimationRate
member.summary: Gets or sets the ExitAnimationRate property. This dependency property indicates the duration or speed at which "exit" animations occur within the panel. If null is specified and the panel belongs to the Layouts collection of a SwitchPanel, then the ExitAnimationRate property of the SwitchPanel will be used. If null is specified and the panel is being used standalone, then a default speed of 1 will be used. To prevent animations within the panel, you can explicitly set the speed property to 0 or simply set the IsAnimated property to false.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Panels.AnimationPanel.ExitAnimator
member.summary: Gets or sets the ExitAnimator property. This dependency property indicates which iterative layout animator will be used to animate children when they are removed from a panel. This provides for an "animate out" effect. If you'd like to use the same animator for several layouts within a SwitchPanel, you can set the ExitAnimator property directly on the owning SwitchPanel. Otherwise, setting this property on an animation panel will override the value of the owning SwitchPanel.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Panels.AnimationPanel.LayoutAnimationRate
member.summary: Gets or sets the LayoutAnimationRate property. This dependency property indicates the duration or speed at which animations occur within the panel. If null is specified and the panel belongs to the Layouts collection of a SwitchPanel, then the LayoutAnimationRate property of the SwitchPanel will be used. If null is specified and the panel is being used standalone, then a default speed of 1 will be used. To prevent animations within the panel, you can explicitly set the speed property to 0 or simply set the IsAnimated property to false.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Panels.AnimationPanel.LayoutAnimator
member.summary: Gets or sets the LayoutAnimator property. This dependency property indicates which iterative layout animator will be used to animate children whenever a layout pass arranges the children to a new location. If the LayoutAnimator property is null, then a linear animator will be used for layout animations. To prevent layout animations, you can set the IsAnimated property to false. If you'd like to use the same animator for several layouts within a SwitchPanel, you can set the LayoutAnimator property directly on the owning SwitchPanel. Otherwise, setting this property on an animation panel will override the value of the owning SwitchPanel.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Panels.AnimationPanel.SwitchAnimationRate
member.summary: Gets or sets the SwitchAnimationRate property. This dependency property indicates the duration or speed at which "switch" animations occur within the panel. If null is specified and the panel belongs to the Layouts collection of a SwitchPanel, then the SwitchAnimationRate property of the SwitchPanel will be used. If UnsetValue is specified and the panel is being used standalone, then a default speed of 1 will be used. To prevent animations within the panel, you can explicitly set the speed property to 0 or simply set the IsAnimated property to false. !!! fix these descriptions

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Panels.AnimationPanel.SwitchAnimator
member.summary: Gets or sets the SwitchAnimator property. This dependency property indicates the animator that will be used for layout switches when the AnimationPanel belongs to the Layouts collection of a SwitchPanel. If the SwitchAnimator property is null, then the LayoutAnimator will be used for both layout animations and switch animations. To prevent switch animations, you can set the AreLayoutSwitchesAnimated property on the owning SwitchPanel to false. If you'd like to use the same animator for all layout switches, you can set the SwitchAnimator property on the owning SwitchPanel.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Panels.AnimationPanel.SwitchParent
member.summary: Gets the SwitchParent property. This dependency property indicates the parent SwitchPanel (if the current SwitchablePanel is a member of a Layouts collection).

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Panels.AnimationPanel.SwitchTemplate
member.summary: Gets or sets the SwitchTemplate property. This dependency property indicates the DataTemplate that should be used for SwitchPresenter elements within the SwitchParent's visual tree while the panel is the active layout of the SwitchParent.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Panels.AnimationPanel.TemplateAnimationRate
member.summary: Gets or sets the TemplateAnimationRate property. This dependency property indicates the duration or speed at which ID'd elements within a SwitchTemplate are animated during a template switch. If null is specified and the panel belongs to the Layouts collection of a SwitchPanel, then the TemplateAnimationRate property of the SwitchPanel will be used. If UnsetValue is specified and the panel is being used standalone, then a default speed of 1 will be used. To prevent animations within the panel, you can explicitly set the speed property to 0 or simply set the IsAnimated property to false.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Panels.AnimationPanel.TemplateAnimator
member.summary: Gets or sets the TemplateAnimator property. This dependency property indicates the animator that will be used for layout switches when the AnimationPanel belongs to the Layouts collection of a SwitchPanel. If the TemplateAnimator property is null, then the LayoutAnimator will be used for both layout animations and switch animations. To prevent switch animations, you can set the AreLayoutSwitchesAnimated property on the owning SwitchPanel to false. If you'd like to use the same animator for all layout switches, you can set the TemplateAnimator property on the owning SwitchPanel.

member.summary: Occurs when a layout animation begins within an AnimationPanel.

member.summary: Occurs when a layout animation completes within an AnimationPanel.

member.name: E:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Panels.AnimationPanel.ChildEntered
member.summary: Occurs when a child enter animation completes. If no enter animation is used, then this event occurse immediately after the child is added to the panel.

member.name: E:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Panels.AnimationPanel.ChildEntering
member.summary: Occurs when a child is first added to the panel. Set the EnterFrom property if you would like an "animate in" effect where the child is animated from the EnterFrom Rect to the ArrangeRect. If EnterFrom is null, the child will simply be arranged at the ArrangeRect location.

member.name: E:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Panels.AnimationPanel.ChildExited
member.summary: Occurs when a child exit animation completes. If no ExitTo rect has been specified, this event is raised immediately after the InitiateChildExit command executes.

member.name: E:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Panels.AnimationPanel.ChildExiting
member.summary: Occurs when a child is about to be removed from the panel. Set the ExitTo property if you would like an "animate out" effect where the child is animated from the ArrangeRect to the ExitTo Rect. Set the Cancel property to true to prevent the exit operation entirely.

member.name: E:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Panels.AnimationPanel.SwitchLayoutDeactivated
member.summary: Occurs when an AnimationPanel that was the active layout panel for a SwitchPanel is no longer the active layout.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Panels.StackDefinition.Length
member.summary: Gets or sets the Length property. This dependency property indicates the size of a given stack within a StackedStackPanel. For a horizontally oriented StackedStackPanel, this would be the width for a given stack. For a vertically oriented StackedStackPanel, this would be the height for a given stack.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Panels.StackDefinition.MaxLength
member.summary: Gets or sets the MaxLength property. This dependency property indicates the maximum size of a given stack in a StackedStackPanel. For a horizontally oriented StackedStackPanel, this would be the maximum stack width for a given stack. For a vertically oriented StackedStackPanel, this would be the maximum stack height for a given stack.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Panels.StackDefinition.MinLength
member.summary: Gets or sets the MinLength property. This dependency property indicates the minimum size of a given stack in a StackedStackPanel. For a horizontally oriented StackedStackPanel, this would be the minimum stack width for a given stack. For a vertically oriented StackedStackPanel, this would be the minimum stack height for a given stack.

member.name: M:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Panels.StackLengthConverter.ConvertFrom(System.ComponentModel.ITypeDescriptorContext,System.Globalization.CultureInfo,System.Object)
member.summary: Attempts to convert to a StackLength from the given object.
member.exception:
An ArgumentNullException is thrown if the example object is null.
An ArgumentException is thrown if the example object is not null and is not a valid type which can be converted to a StackLength.
member.returns: The StackLength instance which was constructed.
member.param: The ITypeDescriptorContext for this call.
The CultureInfo which is respected when converting.
The object to convert to a StackLength.

member.name: M:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Panels.StackLengthConverter.ConvertTo(System.ComponentModel.ITypeDescriptorContext,System.Globalization.CultureInfo,System.Object,System.Type)
member.summary: Attempts to convert a StackLength instance to the given type.
member.exception:
An ArgumentNullException is thrown if the example object is null.
An ArgumentException is thrown if the object is not null and is not a StackLength, or if the destinationType isn't one of the valid destination types.
member.returns: The object which was constructed.
member.param: The ITypeDescriptorContext for this call.
The CultureInfo which is respected when converting.
The StackLength to convert.
The type to which to convert the StackLength instance.

member.name: P:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Panels.SwitchPanel.DefaultAnimationRate
member.summary: Gets or sets the DefaultAnimationRate property. This dependency property indicates the duration or speed at which other animations will occur for panels within the layouts collection that set their respective AnimationRate properties to AnimationRate.Default. This property can be used to set a single animation rate to be used for EnterAnimationRate, ExitAnimationRate, LayoutAnimationRate, SwitchAnimationRate, and TemplateAnimationRate.

member.name: T:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.PropertyGrid.Attributes.DefinitionKeyAttribute
member.summary: The DefinitionKeyAttribute can be assigned to properties of your selected object to define which EditorDefinition to use for the decorated property. As an alternative to the Editor attribute, this allows you separate the UI-specific code from your business model code. It can also be used to specify a specific default editor when a property type does not resolve to a valid editor (e.g., Object).

member.name: T:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Zoombox.ZoomboxViewKind
member.summary: Identifies how content is positioned within a Zoombox.

member.name: F:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Zoombox.ZoomboxViewKind.Absolute
member.summary: Content is positioned absolutely according to the Position and Scale properties of the ZoomboxView.

member.name: F:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Zoombox.ZoomboxViewKind.Fit
member.summary: Content is scaled to fit within the bounds of the Zoombox and positioned according to the HorizontalContentAlignment and VerticalContentAlignment properties of the Zoombox.

member.name: F:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Zoombox.ZoomboxViewKind.Fill
member.summary: Content is scaled to fill the bounds of the Zoombox and positioned according to the HorizontalContentAlignment and VerticalContentAlignment properties of the Zoombox.

member.name: F:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Zoombox.ZoomboxViewKind.Center
member.summary: Content is centered within the Zoombox. The scale of the content is not changed.

member.name: F:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Zoombox.ZoomboxViewKind.Empty
member.summary: Content is not altered in any way.

member.name: F:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Zoombox.ZoomboxViewKind.Region
member.summary: Content is scaled and positioned to view a particular rectangular region identified by the Region property of the ZoomboxView. The region is positioned according to the HorizontalContentAlignment and VerticalContentAlignment properties of the Zoombox.

member.name: T:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Zoombox.ZoomboxViewStackMode
member.summary: Identitifes the way the ViewStack of a Zoombox control is maintained.

member.name: F:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Zoombox.ZoomboxViewStackMode.Auto
member.summary: ViewStack is auto-generated based on user interaction. Each view selected by the user at runtime is added to the stack. Views may also be added and/or altered programmatically.

member.name: F:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Zoombox.ZoomboxViewStackMode.Default
member.summary: Zoombox control will select either Auto or Manual at runtime based on the value of the ViewStackSource property. If ViewStackSource is null, an Auto stack will be maintained. If ViewStackSource is not null, a Manual stack will be used and the views within the view stack will be generated based on the items in the ViewStackSource collection.

member.name: F:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Zoombox.ZoomboxViewStackMode.Disabled
member.summary: ViewStack is not maintained at all for the Zoombox. In this case, the ViewStack property of the Zoombox will return null and an attempt to add views within markup will result in an exception stating that the ViewStack property is readonly.

member.name: F:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Zoombox.ZoomboxViewStackMode.Manual
member.summary: ViewStack is supplied manually at design time or programmatically at runtime and does not change based on user interaction.

member.summary: Scales the content to a specific scale value relative to the ZoomOrigin.

member.summary: Centers the content within the Zoombox control without changing its scale.

member.summary: Scales the content to completely fill the bounds of the Zoombox control.

member.summary: Navigates to the previous view on the view stack.

member.summary: Navigates to the next view on the view stack.

member.name: M:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Zoombox.Zoombox.RefocusView
member.summary: Refocuses the view currently selected within the view stack (the view identified by the ViewStackIndex property).

member.name: M:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Zoombox.Zoombox.Zoom(System.Double)
member.summary: Scales the content by a given percentage relative to the point identified by the ZoomOrigin property.
member.param: The percentage amount by which to scale the content. A positive percentage value will cause the content to scale up (zoom in) and a negative percentage value will cause the content to scale down (zoom out). A value of -20.0, for example, will cause the content to scale down (zoom out) 20%.

member.name: M:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Zoombox.Zoombox.Zoom(System.Double,System.Windows.Point)
member.summary: Scales the content by a given percentage relative to a supplied point.
member.param: The percentage amount by which to scale the content. A positive percentage value will cause the content to scale up (zoom in) and a negative percentage value will cause the content to scale down (zoom out). A value of -20.0, for example, will cause the content to scale down (zoom out) 20%.
The point that will serve as the anchor for the zoom operation. It will remain stationary as the content scales around it. The supplied point must be specified in the coordinate space of the content.

member.name: M:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Zoombox.Zoombox.ZoomTo(System.Windows.Point)
member.summary: Pans the content to the given position without changing its scale.
member.param: The desired top-left point of the content. This position is expressed in the coordinate space of the Zoombox control, not the content.

member.name: M:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Zoombox.Zoombox.ZoomTo(System.Windows.Rect)
member.summary: Zooms the content to a given region.
member.param: The desired rectangular region. This Rect is specified in the coordinate space of the content.

member.name: M:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Zoombox.Zoombox.ZoomTo(System.Double)
member.summary: Zooms the content to the given scale value relative to the point identified by the ZoomOrigin property.
member.param: The scale factor for the content. A value of 1 represents the actual content size. A value greater than 1 will cause the content to zoom in (scale up) and a value less than 1 will cause it to zoom out (scale down).

member.name: M:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Zoombox.Zoombox.ZoomTo(System.Double,System.Windows.Point)
member.summary: Zooms the content to a specific scale value relative to the given point.
member.param: The scale factor for the content. A value of 1 represents the actual content size. A value greater than 1 will cause the content to zoom in (scale up) and a value less than 1 will cause it to zoom out (scale down).
The point that will serve as the anchor for the zoom operation. It will remain stationary as the content scales around it. The supplied point must be specified in the coordinate space of the content.

member.name: M:Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Zoombox.Zoombox.ZoomTo(Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit.Zoombox.ZoomboxView)
member.summary: Zooms the content to a specific view.
member.param: Identifies the view that will be focused.
